Title: An attributional theory of convergent thinking in groups
Source title: Academy of Management 2006 Annual Meeting: Knowledge, Action and the Public Concern, AOM 2006
Abstract: Classic research on attribution theory suggests that groups are biased toward attributing their success to factors that are internal to their group. However, the existing research has confounded two types of attributions that are both internal to the group, but theoretically distinct: (1) Attributions that differentiate between the contributions made by each individual group member and (2) Attributions that focus on the group as a whole. This dichotomy is important because different types of attributions may have different consequences for convergent thinking in groups (Goncalo, 2004). This prediction was tested in an experiment in which groups explored alternative courses of action prior to making a shared decision. The results showed that attribution for past success focused on the group as a whole caused groups to consider fewer alternatives and less divergent alternatives. These findings suggest that the group serving bias may have important consequences for group performance that have not yet been considered in current research.
Index Keywords: Convergent thinkings; Group members; Group performance

Title: The challenge of increasing minority faculty representation in U. S. business schools: An empirical examination into what matters most (and it's not what you think)
Source title: Academy of Management 2006 Annual Meeting: Knowledge, Action and the Public Concern, AOM 2006
Abstract: Census statistics highlight the increasing diversity of the U. S. populace. The U. S. Census Bureau (2002) projected that by 2025, white non-Hispanic Americans will comprise 62% and minority Americans 38% of the U. S. population. Business students need to be able to work effectively with others of different backgrounds ethnicities and values. Interaction with minority faculty helps students develop this competency. Recent surveys indicate that business school leaders and students realize the positive benefits minority faculty bring to the learning experience. However U. S.-born minority faculty are underrepresented in AACSB business schools relative to their representation in the U. S. population. Theoretical explanations for lagging minority faculty representation have been advanced but have received little empirical attention. Six of these theories argue that low minority representation is due to a lack of diversity sensitivity on the part of educational leaders, discrimination the (small) pipeline of qualified minority faculty, equal opportunity theory, rational person economic theory, and low institutional diversity strategic priority. These six arguments are explored and tested in U. S. business schools. Results indicated that leader racial awareness, perceived importance of cultural change, recruitment and feedback efforts predicted minority faculty representation at U. S. business schools. Salary levels were associated with minority representation but the direction of the relationship did not support our hypothesis. Diversity strategic priority failed to predict minority representation. Implications and future research directions are discussed.

Title: Steps towards a theory of institutional stability and change as dialectically related opposites
Source title: Academy of Management 2006 Annual Meeting: Knowledge, Action and the Public Concern, AOM 2006
Abstract: This paper argues that recent attempts to transform and/or extend new institutional theory to explain institutional change fail to overcome new institutionalism's limited capacity to deal with the question of change for two reasons. First, there is a tendency to preserve the dualism of structural constraint and free agency. Second, they tend to rely on functionalist explanations to account for institutional change. It is argued that a social constructionist theory of institutional change that frames institutional stability and change as dialectically related opposites has the potential to overcome these two significant shortcomings. Mainly drawing upon Berger & Luckmann (1967)'s seminal account of social constructionism, which paradoxically forms an important part of new institutional theory's microsociological underpinnings, the paper identifies and explores 10 sources of institutional stability. These sources are developed into a proposition framework for institutional stability analysis that can be used to explore questions of institutional change. The application of this framework to the everyday example of 'queuing' is used to illustrate the paper's main contention that it is through stability analysis that specific institutional change sequences can be better understood.

Index Keywords: Functionalist explanations; Institutional change; Institutional stabilities; Institutional theory; New Institutional Theory; Social constructionism; Stability analysis; Structural constraints; Stability

Title: "re-evaluating diversity": Reviving critical discourse in diversity research in organization studies
Source title: Academy of Management 2006 Annual Meeting: Knowledge, Action and the Public Concern, AOM 2006
Abstract: For over 20 years, organizational researchers have acknowledged a need to study, understand, and even promote diversity in the workplace as a means of acknowledging differences in relation to changes in the demographic environments, particularly in the US. Yet most of this worked has not focused on challenging underlying assumptions that help to reproduce problems associated with differences in the workplace. As a result, the theoretical development, and societal impact of diversity research by organizational scholars has been rather limited in scope. It is the premise of this essay that more critical or challenging stances still need to be applied that question the underlying assumptions of research on diversity, particularly among US management scholars. This paper includes an overview of the dominant perspectives and arguments about diversity in organizational studies, particularly in organizational behavior with a more critical lens applied to some of the more recent reviews of work in the field. The particular focus here is on how the texts and language produced in the organizational literature on diversity are engaged in a politics of representation that keeps organizations separate and inequitable, despite the rhetoric of "valuing' differences. This approach is adopted to introduce new questions that need to be addressed if we are to seriously approach diversity issues in management research and transform our prior understandings of what constitutes knowledge, theory, and practice in organization studies.

Title: The moderating effects of technological capabilities on the market pioneering - Firm survival relationship
Source title: Academy of Management 2006 Annual Meeting: Knowledge, Action and the Public Concern, AOM 2006
Abstract: A core idea in corporate entrepreneurship is that strategic renewal requires a syncretic balance between product and markets on one hand, and exploration and exploitation on the other. This paper investigates firm performance in industries where rapid changes are accompanied by the emergence of new technological sub-fields and market segments. We re-examine first mover advantage (FMA) by adopting a dynamic, evolutionary conceptualization of first movers, and in the context of the technological 'play' of the product being launched. In the empirical setting of the disk drive industry during 1977-1997, we show that a firm's technological capability has crucial implications on the outcome of its market pioneering efforts. We demonstrate that while pioneering elevates survival rates when a firm is a technology leader, such early to market strategies hurt when the technological performance of the product is below a certain minimum level. Until a firm accomplishes this minimum of technological play in the product, a firm is better off delaying entry even in product markets that have very short life-cycles.

Title: Trust in developing relationships: From theory to measurement
Source title: Academy of Management 2006 Annual Meeting: Knowledge, Action and the Public Concern, AOM 2006
Abstract: To date there has been little empirical research on Lewicki and Bunker's (1995, 1996) multidimensional conceptual framework for understanding the facets of trust within interpersonal relationships-calculusbased, knowledge-based, and identification-based trust-and the processes by which trust relationships emerge and evolve over time. We present the findings of three empirical studies focused on systematic and progressive refinement and validation of a measure of interpersonal trust aligned with this framework. Factor analysis and comparative analyses reported in study 1 show that the three constructs are distinct. However, comparative analyses of responses across contexts revealed that the calculus-based measure was not a form of trust. Furthermore, an additional affect-based trust construct was identified. Factor analysis and invariance test results reported in Study 2 highlight the robustness of knowledge-based, identification-based and affect-based trust measures across three distinct relational settings-trust between coworkers, trust of supervisors in subordinates, and trust of employees in their supervisors. Evidence from longitudinal research, reported in Study 3, shows that trust develops within relationships over time and that the three trust constructs differentially predict trust outcomes. While knowledge-based trust uniquely predicted influence tactic use, all three forms of trust predicted task assistance and reliance, and affect-based trust predicted socio-emotional support provision and self-disclosure. Taken together, the findings across three empirical studies, conducted with very different samples and methodologies, highlight the strength of a new set of measures for empirical work based upon Lewicki and Bunker's developmental theory of trust.

Title: The allocation of ownership rights in consulting firms
Source title: Academy of Management 2006 Annual Meeting: Knowledge, Action and the Public Concern, AOM 2006
Abstract: This paper investigates the antecedents of the allocation of ownership rights to inside or outside parties in the case of large consulting firms. We draw on organizational economics in order to develop hypotheses which we then test using regression analyses. The results confirm the significance of capital requirements, business risk, agency costs and the costs of collective decision-making as determinants of the allocation of ownership rights in consulting firms. Our findings provide support for economic theories emphasizing the motivation, incentive and control effects that are associated with the allocation of ownership rights.

Title: Corruption and entrepreneurship: How formal and informal institutions shape firm behavior in mature and emerging market economies
Source title: Academy of Management 2006 Annual Meeting: Knowledge, Action and the Public Concern, AOM 2006
Abstract: Using data from the World Business Environment Survey (2000), this study analyzes the determinants of corruption focusing on the country's institutional make-up and the role it plays for corrupt behavior of entrepreneurs. A cross-national comparison supports the hypothesis that the entrepreneurs' corrupt behavior is shaped by both formal (economic and legal rules or organizations) and informal institutions (culturally embedded codes of conduct, norms and values). Minimizing transaction costs seems to play a crucial role for becoming engaged in corruption. The higher costs associated with protecting the property rights, enforcing legal decisions, or simply interpreting business laws and regulations, the higher the entrepreneur's willingness to pay bribes. Similarly, the inadequacy of financial institutions in assisting entrepreneurship results in higher willingness of engaging in corruption. On the other hand, also informal institutions matter. More specifically, the entrepreneur's embeddedness in "closed" (business) networks (with friends, kin, and national bureaucrats) nurtures corrupt deals. Furthermore, business ethics governed by the principle if "others behave illegally, so can I" establish breeding grounds for corruption.

Title: Ambidexterity in corporate venturing: Simultaneously using existing and building new capabilities
Source title: Academy of Management 2006 Annual Meeting: Knowledge, Action and the Public Concern, AOM 2006
Abstract: While corporate venture units are typically viewed as vehicles for exploration (March, 1991), we develop a model of corporate venture units as essentially ambidextrous (Duncan, 1976; Tushman & O'Reilly, 1996), i.e. as engaging in both exploration and exploitation. We examine how corporate venture units develop ambidexterity, as well as the impact of ambidexterity on their performance. We use questionnaire data collected from 95 corporate venture units. There are two key findings. First, those venture units reporting a high level of strategic performance rate high on both exploitation (using existing corporate capabilities) and exploration (building new capabilities). Second, ambidextrous corporate venture units (i.e. those focusing on using and building capabilities) exhibit particular patterns of relationships with three sets of actors - senior executives in the parent company, other business units in the parent company, and members of the venture capital community.

Title: The predisposition to engage in interpersonal deviance at work
Source title: Academy of Management 2006 Annual Meeting: Knowledge, Action and the Public Concern, AOM 2006
Abstract: As predicted by self-control theory, data collected from two separate organizations revealed a consistent relationship between the conscientiousness x extroversion x agreeableness interaction and managerratings of interpersonal deviance. Specifically, at low levels of agreeableness, individuals who are highly extroverted and low in conscientiousness received the highest ratings of interpersonal deviance. However, at high levels of agreeableness, highly extroverted and low conscientious individuals received the lowest ratings of interpersonal deviance. Implications for managers and future research are discussed.

Title: Leader-Member Social Exchange (LMSX): Development and validation of a scale
Source title: Academy of Management 2006 Annual Meeting: Knowledge, Action and the Public Concern, AOM 2006
Abstract: Recent research has argued that current Leader-Member Exchange (LMX) scales do not adequately assess the social exchange between a leader and a subordinate. In this article, we developed and validated a new scale we label, Leader-Member Social Exchange (LMSX). Our findings indicated LMSX appears to assess the construct of social exchange in leader-member relations. Included in LMSX development were three independent studies consisting of an item analysis by 24 leading LMX researchers, an initial questionnaire administration to 110 public and private sector workers, and a third study including 195 matched employee/supervisor pairs. Collectively, LMSX offers an alternative LMX scale that is consistent with current exchanged-based definitions of LMX.
Index Keywords: Current leaders; Item analysis; Leader members; Public and private sector; Recent researches; Social exchange; Public administration

Title: Dynamic theory of multimarket contact: Competence depletion, punctuated forbearance, performance
Source title: Academy of Management 2006 Annual Meeting: Knowledge, Action and the Public Concern, AOM 2006
Abstract: Multimarket contact (MMC) theory maintains that firms confronting one another simultaneously in multiple markets tacitly collude to reduce the intensity of inter-firm rivalry. This study argues that the profitenhancing effects of MMC's short-term collusive outcomes are more than offset in the long-term by the performance-depleting convergence of MMC's intra-firm and population-level consequences. At the firm level, rivalry reduction, mimicry, and myopia deriving from multimarket contact mediate competency depletion over time by decreasing problemistic search, increasing path dependence, reducing competitive experience, inducing mimetic isomorphism, promoting macrocultures, and locking the firm into foothold commitments. At the population level, multimarket contact destabilizes concentration levels, generating patterns of 'punctuated forbearance' in which flurries of intense rivalry interrupt extended periods of tacit collusion. The confluence of firm-level competence depletion and population-level punctuated forbearance, I conclude, undermines long-term firm performance. Punctuated forbearance ultimately exposes the very competence depletion which it largely drives and from which it partially derives.
Index Keywords: Competence depletion; Concentration levels; Firm Performance; Increasing paths; Multi-market contacts; Multiple markets; Population levels; Tacit collusion; Locks (fasteners)

Title: Knowledge ownership and territoriality: A conceptualization and scenario-based experimental investigation
Source title: Academy of Management 2006 Annual Meeting: Knowledge, Action and the Public Concern, AOM 2006
Abstract: During the course of knowledge creation, employees develop psychological ownership (PO) feelings toward knowledge and express those feelings overtly or covertly by exhibiting territorial behaviors such as identity-oriented and control-oriented marking of knowledge. Those territorial behaviors can lead to disputes between firms and employees over the ownership of knowledge. To minimize such outcomes, many firms institute intellectual property (IP) policies. This study examines the effect of firms' IP policies on employees' territorial behaviors around knowledge. In a scenario-based experimental study, we find that knowledge workers perceive certain IP policies as infringement of their own knowledge territory. In response, they exhibit strong emotional reactions, reduce their intention to create knowledge for the firm, and increase their intention to legally challenge the firm's ownership of the knowledge.

Title: Status and the social construction of workplace deviance
Source title: Academy of Management 2006 Annual Meeting: Knowledge, Action and the Public Concern, AOM 2006
Abstract: While acknowledging the potential for workplace deviance to be socially constructed, researchers have paid little attention to factors that systematically alter evaluations of bad behavior in organizations. We show that the ascribed status of actors and evaluators influences perceptions of the seriousness of workplace deviance. Participants in a survey experiment rated identical sets of deviant behavior to be more serious when enacted by low- vs. high-status targets (i.e., women vs. men, Blacks vs. Whites). As predicted, high-status evaluators (i.e., men) were more discriminatory than low-status evaluators in their judgments, such that they were more lenient toward high- vs. low-status targets.

Title: Do ties break from the changing of the guard? Executive mobility and the market ties of firms
Source title: Academy of Management 2006 Annual Meeting: Knowledge, Action and the Public Concern, AOM 2006
Abstract: We test the proposition that the mobility of top managers in advertisers and advertising agencies weakens client-agency relationships. Social embeddedness theory suggests that if client-agency relationships are embedded in top managers' social relations then the exit of top managers should increase the likelihood of their dissolution. However, previous research on advertising agencies has failed to find empirical support for this prediction, casting doubt on social embeddedness arguments. We investigate executive mobility and market tie dissolutions in samples of advertisers and advertising agencies and find support for social embeddedness but not always in the ways predicted by previous research. For advertisers, the dissolution of market ties depends not on the exit of executives but by how executive vacancies are filled. For advertisers, the exit of incumbents and internal succession weaken market ties, but these effects depend on the size and strategy of advertising agencies. We discuss the implications of these findings for social embeddedness theory and research on market ties and executive mobility.

Title: Overcoming the MUM effect in it project reporting: The effect of time pressure and blame shifting
Source title: Academy of Management 2006 Annual Meeting: Knowledge, Action and the Public Concern, AOM 2006
Abstract: Troubled projects are a common problem in the information systems field. While there is a natural reluctance to report the actual status of a troubled project, doing so is sometimes the only way that the project can be brought to senior management's attention so that corrective actions can be taken to successfully turn the project around if possible, or abandon it if necessary. Prior research has suggested that the ability to save face and time pressure are two variables that may impact bad news reporting. In this paper, we examine the effect that a blame shifting opportunity (as a mechanism for saving face) has on an individual's assessment of whether a troubled project's status ought to be reported and on that individual's willingness to report. We also examine the effect that perceived time urgency has on all three constructs in the basic whistle-blowing model adapted from Dozier and Miceli (1985). Based on the results of a controlled laboratory experiment, we find that both blame shifting and time urgency are important factors affecting an individual's willingness to report bad news. Blame shifting exerts both direct and indirect influence on willingness to report bad news, while time urgency was found only to exert an indirect influence on willingness to report bad news. The implications of these findings and directions for future research are discussed.

Title: Effect of workaholism on managerial performance: Help or hindrance?
Source title: Academy of Management 2006 Annual Meeting: Knowledge, Action and the Public Concern, AOM 2006
Abstract: We examined the effect of workaholism on managers' (N =346) performance, using 360-degree performance data provided by their colleagues. The effects of two dimensions of workaholism, drive and work enjoyment, were tested. We found that work enjoyment, the extent to which individuals work because they find it pleasurable or interesting, was positively related to performance. Managers who had higher levels of work enjoyment received higher performance ratings. Drive, the compulsion to work hard due to inner pressures, moderated the effect of work enjoyment on performance. When drive was low, work enjoyment was positively related to performance; performance ratings increased as work enjoyment increased. When managers were highly driven, however, work enjoyment was not related to performance. Excessive drive seemed to interfere with the performance-enhancing aspects of work enjoyment. Overall, our findings suggest that work enjoyment is 'a help' to performance. Its beneficial effects, however, may be hindered by excessive drive.

Title: Local and non-local pre-founding experience and organizational form transformation: The case of the Israeli wine industry
Source title: Academy of Management 2006 Annual Meeting: Knowledge, Action and the Public Concern, AOM 2006
Abstract: The twin expectations of local imprinting and of organizational form inertia (Stinchcombe, 1965) make it difficult to see how we ever observe form changes within local populations of organizations. In this paper, we present a theory of new form invasion that features both local and non-local pre-founding industry experience as drivers of both organizational form selection and performance with the selected forms. This theory further suggests a blending process. Pre-founding experience in non-local populations leads founders to establish organizations with the novel forms. When these founders also have pre-founding experience in the local population, their new organizations tend to perform better. This facilitates the establishment and persistence of the new organizational form. We evaluate these predictions in an analysis of a major transformation of the population of Israeli wineries. Between 1982 and 2003, the population of Israeli wine producers grew from just five to more than 100. This explosion in numbers coincided with a shift toward non-kosher wine production. Although the four largest Israeli producers in 1982 were kosher, roughly eighty percent of the new entrants were established as non-kosher producers. After arguing that kosher versus non-kosher wine production represent two distinct organizational forms separated (at least initially) by strong form boundaries, we analyze how the novel non-kosher organizational form successfully invaded the local population of kosher producers. Our results attest to the joint effect of local and non-local pre-founding experience, and thus corroborate our theory of form invasion.

Title: Geographic signatures: Firm proximities and performance
Source title: Academy of Management 2006 Annual Meeting: Knowledge, Action and the Public Concern, AOM 2006
Abstract: Research on firm location typically adopts a regional perspective and ascribes cluster benefits to firms. This study considers a firm's complete national geographic presence, including their sub-units, relative to all other firms. We focus on the US pharmaceutical and biotechnology industries due to their knowledgeintensive nature. We carefully define the two industries as 'alter' to each other. Higher firm level performance is associated with greater scattering of a firm's sub-units. There are surprising adverse effects of proximity to firms in the 'alter' industry and no effect of proximity to directly competing firms in the 'ego' industry.

Title: Getting influence: How an organizational group gains action on environmental issues over time
Source title: Academy of Management 2006 Annual Meeting: Knowledge, Action and the Public Concern, AOM 2006
Abstract: This paper considers how a relatively powerless group advances environmental issues within an organization over time. Using longitudinal ethnographic, archival and interview data spanning six years, it describes the practices used by members of a high-tech manufacturer to introduce environmental considerations into the design of new manufacturing processes. Three distinct patterns of practice were used over time, but only the last one, "setting problems," was successfully used to integrate the environmental considerations. The analysis builds on insights from the literatures on issue selling and knowledge boundaries to offer a dynamic explanation for how new issues are advanced by a less powerful group, focusing on specific practices that evolve and accumulate over time, in response to differences in resources, norms, and meaning encountered at boundaries.

Title: Leveraging social networks and team configuration to enhance knowledge access in distributed teams
Source title: Academy of Management 2006 Annual Meeting: Knowledge, Action and the Public Concern, AOM 2006
Abstract: Increasingly organizations are utilizing geographically distributed teams to accomplish their goals. To a great extent this new way of working has been made possible by electronic communication technology. Yet even while managers are leveraging electronic communication technology to gain access to new knowledge and to enable new team configurations, they are concerned about the knowledge acquisition of distributed team members who interact primarily via electronic communication. The objective of this study is to deepen our understanding of the relationship of electronic communication technology use and team configuration with knowledge access in distributed teams. We do so by examining the communication networks of individuals in distributed teams, and the relationship of team configuration on those networks. We extend prior work on social networks and propose that individuals in distributed teams have two distinct communication networks that influence knowledge access: face-to-face and electronic networks. We find that these two networks differentially influence an individual's level of knowledge access from team members. In addition, we find that the relationship of each of these networks with knowledge access level is influenced by how the team is physically configured and the size of the team. These findings suggest that achieving higher knowledge access levels in distributed teams is more complex than just increasing electronic and face-to-face communication. Rather it involves understanding how communication patterns, communication mode and team configuration interact to influence the level of knowledge access for each individual in the team.

Title: Rich versus king: The entrepreneur's dilemma
Source title: Academy of Management 2006 Annual Meeting: Knowledge, Action and the Public Concern, AOM 2006
Abstract: The two major motivations to start a new venture are the profit motive and the control motive. This paper examines how entrepreneurs' choices that increase their potential financial gains (i.e., achieve the profit motive) should conflict with their ability to achieve the control motive. In particular, it focuses on how attracting the external resources required to build value can conflict with entrepreneurs' abilities to keep control of their ventures at the CEO and board levels. It explores whether this tension exists both at the level of the individual entrepreneur's financial gains and at the level of the overall venture's value, and also whether entrepreneurs can avoid the tradeoff by building more human capital before founding the venture and by retaining more co-founders as the venture grows. It tests its hypotheses on a unique dataset of 457 private technology ventures, and finds strong support for each of its core propositions. Implications include the need for entrepreneurs to understand the small probability of achieving both the profit and control motives, and to examine their core motivation and proactively plan their strategic choices to achieve that motivation.

Title: Adding value to others: The positive externalities of social capital
Source title: Academy of Management 2006 Annual Meeting: Knowledge, Action and the Public Concern, AOM 2006
Abstract: The importance of social structure to an actor's private ambitions, such as power, job attainment, career advancement, is well explored. Less well understood are the positive externalities of social structure, a viewpoint on social structure as a public good. This paper concerns how some 1800 professional service employees -bankers - operating in a large investment bank cooperate and add value to one another in the course of everyday work. The main question we ask is whether social structure can help explain why some employees are better able than others to add value to their peers, as rated by their peers. Our theoretical contribution concerns the distinct influences of two orders of social capital: first-order and second-order. First-order social capital is conceptualized as the social structure of the focal actor. Second-order social capital is conceptualized as the social structure of the actor's boss, a central figure in the life of most managers. Our concern, then, is with two complementary externalities of social structure: the focal actor's and his/her boss's. Using network sparseness to capture social capital, we find that both first-order and second-order social capital have a significant effect on how much value an employee adds to others. Thus, we document not only how an actor's social capital might also act as a public good, increasing the value the actor adds to others, but also how in this capacity, the actor can further benefit from the social capital of the boss, a prominent contact.

Title: Linking behavioral control to employee outcomes: Testing two explanations using motivation theories
Source title: Academy of Management 2006 Annual Meeting: Knowledge, Action and the Public Concern, AOM 2006
Abstract: We examine the intermediate role of job autonomy and situational learning orientation in linking behavioral control to employee commitment and performance. Data from 1184 service employees and their supervisors indicate that situational learning orientation is important in linking behavioral control to performance. Job autonomy shows to be important in explaining employee outcomes but is as such only marginally related to behavioral control.
Index Keywords: Personnel; Behavioral control; Employee commitment; Learning orientation; Motivation theories; Service employees; Control theory

Title: Human element in DoD's transformation
Source title: Academy of Management 2006 Annual Meeting: Knowledge, Action and the Public Concern, AOM 2006
Abstract: Half of the efforts to transform organizations fail to achieve the desired results. In 2005, the Department of Defense (DoD) expected to spend billions of dollars on an expensive and risky undertaking-the transformation of DoD. In this study I refer to that transformation as planned organizational change and explore the experiences of two groups of stakeholders: planners/implementers and contributors/recipients. Three concepts-stakeholder, planned change, and sensemaking-provide the theoretical framework. The research question is: How do internal stakeholders in Federal defense organizations experience and make sense of planned organizational change? This phenomenographic (Marton, 1981, 2000) study explores the different ways in which these stakeholders experience, conceptualize, and make sense of planned organizational change. Weick's seven properties of sensemaking (1995; 2001) help reveal the meaning aspect of their experiences. Conceptions about the philosophy of the change experience range from "It's the right thing to do" to "It's the banner of the moment" to "It's political." A key finding is the variation in the support for participants' sensemaking, where members of the planner/implementer stakeholder group indicated more support for their sensemaking than the contributor/recipient stakeholder group. Four variations in stakeholders' experience of planned organizational change emerged. These variations, or categories of description, are: aligned, conflicted, disillusioned, and dysfunctional. These are presented in an empirical typology or outcome space. Finally, this study adds to the collective understanding of the human element of organizational transformation by presenting a model of how internal stakeholder experience planned organizational change.
Index Keywords: Department of Defense; Organizational change; Organizational transformation; Phenomenography; Research questions; Sensemaking; Stakeholder groups; Theoretical framework; Network security

Title: Facilitating learning from front-line failures
Source title: Academy of Management 2006 Annual Meeting: Knowledge, Action and the Public Concern, AOM 2006
Abstract: This paper investigates the conditions under which front-line employees are more likely to attempt organizational learning from work system failures. Drawing on organizational behavior and quality improvement literatures, we develop a framework of front-line problem-solving, which is tested using survey data from employees and managers from 48 different work units. We also present observational data from four of these units. We find that psychological safety-the belief that one can talk about one's own or others' errors without risk of punishment-and problem solving efficacy-the belief that the organization will respond positively to employees' suggestions on system improvements-was correlated with work units' levels of front-line problem-solving activities, which in turn was associated with employee satisfaction. Surprisingly, individuals felt responsibility was not associated with front-line problem-solving. These findings suggest that rather than relying on hiring motivated individuals, managers instead need to create an environment that fosters employees' efforts to improve their work systems. To create such an environment managers must ensure that employees have sufficient time to engage in improvement efforts, create a work culture where it is safe to talk about work system problems and follow through on employee communications. Doing so can result in improved work processes and ultimately, better outcomes.
Index Keywords: Managers; Systems engineering; Employee communication; Employee satisfaction; Front line employees; Organizational behavior; Organizational learning; Psychological safety; Quality improvement; System improvements; Human resource management

Title: Managing liquidity in research-intensive firms: Signaling effects of patents & managerial ownership
Source title: Academy of Management 2006 Annual Meeting: Knowledge, Action and the Public Concern, AOM 2006
Abstract: The effective holding and management of liquid assets is critical to success in research-intensive industries. We examine this issue and suggest that contracting and competitive environments facing research-intensive firms will determine the level of liquid assets held by the firm. Specifically, we suggest that a firm's research & development investments positively predict the level of its liquid asset holdings. This is due to the fact that invention-induced knowledge asymmetries increase the firm's cost of accessing external liquid capital. However, we also find that patent production and top manager ownership provide important signaling mechanisms which reduce knowledge asymmetries between the firm and capital markets, and consequently lower the firm's need to hold liquid assets. Empirical tests were conducted using a sample of 105 U.S.-based biotechnology firms.
Index Keywords: Managers; Patents and inventions; Biotechnology firms; Competitive environment; Development investment; Empirical test; Liquid asset; Signaling mechanisms; Top managers; Liquids

Title: Promise and problems with supply chain management approaches to health care purchasing
Source title: Academy of Management 2006 Annual Meeting: Knowledge, Action and the Public Concern, AOM 2006
Abstract: The return of double-digit health care inflation coupled with widespread reports of poor care quality and deadly medical errors have caused private sector employers to reevaluate their health benefits purchasing strategies, with a focus on supply chain management (SCM) approaches. In other industries, this purchasing strategy has proven to be an effective method in simultaneously reducing costs and increasing quality; adoption of this approach in the health care industry has recently begun. The purpose of this paper is to describe the application of SCM methodologies to health care purchasing and to identify its potential strengths and weaknesses in controlling cost and increasing quality and value. While several nationwide efforts are gaining some traction in the marketplace, at this time, no cost reduction and quality improvement program initiative appears to systematically align the entire health care supply chain from providers' inputs to purchasers' payments, raising doubt about the ability of SCM techniques to significantly impact the health care marketplace in the short-run.
Index Keywords: Commerce; Cost reduction; Health care; Sales; Controlling costs; Health benefits; Healthcare industry; Medical errors; Private-sector employers; Quality improvement program; Reducing costs; Supply chain managements (SCM); Supply chain management

Title: The impact of founder's ownership, social capital and investors on IPO stockmarket performance
Source title: Academy of Management 2006 Annual Meeting: Knowledge, Action and the Public Concern, AOM 2006
Abstract: Signaling theory argues that entrepreneurs can send signals that indicate the expected value of a venture. Connecting signaling theory to the role of information asymmetry in pricing of IPOs it has been argued that the appropriate signals from the entrepreneur can in turn limit the underpricing of a stock. Prior research has not always given clear indications whether managers can send signals that effect underpricing. This research employs finer grained methods and finds that entrepreneur's ownership as a signal of value perceived in the firm can limit underpricing. However, this occurs only to a certain level. After the entrepreneur's ownership reaches too high a level, its impact on underpricing becomes positive, underpricing increases. This research also presents evidence that business angels, as distinct from venture capitalists, are a signal that helps to reduce underpricing. The impact of these findings on practice and future research are detailed in the manuscript.
Index Keywords: Business angels; Expected values; Information asymmetry; Signaling theory; Social capitals; Venture capitalists; Navigation

Title: Boundary work tactics: Negotiating the work-home interface
Source title: Academy of Management 2006 Annual Meeting: Knowledge, Action and the Public Concern, AOM 2006
Abstract: We document how members of a particularly problematic occupation engage in boundary work to negotiate the demands between work and home life. Building upon Nippert-Eng's (1996) notion of "boundary work," we discovered and classified physical, behavioral, cognitive, and temporal tactics that subjects used to help create their ideal level of work-family segmentation. Our findings are based two qualitative studies with Episcopal priests. The first involved analysis of open-ended surveys of 220 priests, while the second involved detailed coding of hour-long interviews with 60 other priests. Our findings extend past theoretical and empirical work by demonstrating individuals' abilities to effectuate desired changes in their work-home balance.
Index Keywords: Boundary works; Home life; Qualitative study; Work-family; Work-life balance

Title: Meta-analytic tests of justice & OCB: Agent-system, agentdominance, & shared-variance models
Source title: Academy of Management 2006 Annual Meeting: Knowledge, Action and the Public Concern, AOM 2006
Abstract: Two competing perspectives may explain the patterns of unique effects among types of perceived fairness on citizenship behavior that benefits individuals (OCB-I) and organizations (OCB-O): the agentsystem model (interactional and procedural justice are the strongest unique predictors of OCB-I and OCB-O, respectively) and the agent-dominance model (interactional justice is the strongest unique predictor of all OCB). Another perspective suggests that shared variance among justice types predicts OCB. Analyses of semi-partial correlations conducted on meta-analytic coefficients clarified previous support for agent-system and agent-dominance models. Shared variance among the justice types accounted for substantial justice-OCB covariance. We discuss theoretical and practical implications.
Index Keywords: Agent systems; Fairness; Justice; Organizational citizenship behaviors; Partial correlation; Procedural justice; Variance models

Title: A contingency theory of political connections: Business group diversification in emverging economies
Source title: Academy of Management 2006 Annual Meeting: Knowledge, Action and the Public Concern, AOM 2006
Abstract: This paper examines how formal and informal political connections facilitate business group diversification in an emerging economy before and after political liberalization. We study diversification by the top 100 business groups in Taiwan from 1986 to 1994. We find that formal political connections with national leaders facilitate diversification prior to liberalization, but only informal connections to legislators and officials contribute to diversification after liberalization. The analysis rejects the possibility that diversification might lead to creating connections. The study contributes to studies of business groups in emerging economies, as well as to the more general literatures on diversification and political strategy.
Author Keywords: Business groups; Emerging economies; Political connections
Index Keywords: Business groups; Contingency theory; Emerging economies; Political Connections

Title: Never too early, never too late: Effects of search timing on product innovation
Source title: Academy of Management 2006 Annual Meeting: Knowledge, Action and the Public Concern, AOM 2006
Abstract: This paper focuses on how firms search for new products. In contrast with the traditional firm-centric view, we study how timing of a firm's search depends on that of its competitors. Using 15 years of longitudinal data on 71 Japanese, European, and American industrial automation organizations, we find that innovative firms search early or late, but not in sync with competitors. Moreover, those that are most innovative combine the two, and search early and late. We also find that early movers are especially innovative when their competitors are slow to catch up. In contrast, late movers are especially innovative when they wait to learn from competitors what not to do, yet move fast enough before all opportunities are exploited. The results also show that the effects of timing vary with organizational form: focused firms are successful when they search early, and diversified firms when they search late. Our findings have implications for theories of search, resources, and inter-organizational learning.

Title: Diversification and performance: Linking relatedness, market structure and the decision to diversify
Source title: Academy of Management 2006 Annual Meeting: Knowledge, Action and the Public Concern, AOM 2006
Abstract: An extensive empirical literature in strategy and finance concerns the performance implications of corporate diversification. Two core debates concern the existence of a diversification discount and the relative importance of market relatedness and market structure for the performance of diversifiers. We address these debates by building a formal model in which the extent of diversification is endogenous and affects both market structure and firms' competitiveness. Our model elucidates the interdependent impact of structure and relatedness on performance. We find a non-monotonic effect of relatedness on performance: while greater relatedness increases the competitiveness of diversified firms, it can also spur additional diversification, thereby eroding market structure and performance. We use the model to generate data and show how the negative effect of relatedness on market structure can give rise to a spurious inference of a diversification discount in cross-sectional regressions.

Title: The white standard in leadership evaluations: Attributional benefits of a white corporate leader
Source title: Academy of Management 2006 Annual Meeting: Knowledge, Action and the Public Concern, AOM 2006
Abstract: Relative to White corporate leaders, African-Americans have typically been under-represented in upperlevel management and this study investigated whether psychological biases contribute to this under representation. In all, 479 participants from different racial backgrounds (African-American, White, Asian, and Hispanic) evaluated a White or African-American CEO's leadership effectiveness after finding that the CEO's company had a recent record of financial success or failure, and that the company's performance was attributable to the CEO's leadership or to environmental conditions. Results showed that White CEOs were considered much more effective than African-American CEOs when a company's success was attributed to the CEO's leadership, but that White CEOs were considered less responsible than African-American CEOs when an organization's failure was attributed to the CEO's leadership. Participants' race did not moderate these effects. Evidence from this study and a supplementary pilot test support the idea that White leaders are evaluated more favorably because they are considered more prototypical leaders.

Title: Of maps and managers: Toward a cognitive theory of strategic intervention
Source title: Academy of Management 2006 Annual Meeting: Knowledge, Action and the Public Concern, AOM 2006
Abstract: Researchers in the field of managerial cognition are concerned with the way organizational decision makers mentally represent strategic issues and problems, and with how this influences their handling of strategic activities. It is often posited that changing actors' mental representations can enhance strategic adaptation and responsiveness. However, this area of study is fragmented and lacks a unifying theoretical framework. To redress these limitations, we develop a theory of how techniques such as cognitive mapping can achieve appropriate changes in managers' mental representations. Our theory outlines three sequenced processes and corresponding outcomes that are integral to successful cognitive change: differentiation, integration, and coherence of knowledge. We analyze the representational and processing characteristics of differentiated, integrated, and coherent knowledge, and the psychological mechanisms by which this can be attained with intervention techniques used by management researchers and practitioners. We synthesize theory and research from cognitive psychology concerning how mental representations (including categories, schemata, and mental models) and information processing (specifically the functions of working memory and dual processing) influence problem solving and decision making with research from behavioral decision theory and managerial cognition. In doing so, we explicate how several limitations and biases afflicting strategic thinking can be overcome based on the principles of differentiation, integration, and coherence. Propositions predict the specific benefits these provide for managerial decision making and problem solving, including improved usage of information relevant to a problem, the development of richer and more effective mental models, and the minimization of errors and biases in strategic thinking.
Author Keywords: Cognitive map; Coherence; Differentiation; Integration; Strategic intervention

Title: Strategies for the management of intellectual property rights in service-intensive companies
Source title: Academy of Management 2006 Annual Meeting: Knowledge, Action and the Public Concern, AOM 2006
Abstract: As in the manufacturing sector, the protection of innovation and knowledge in service-intensive industries is important to guarantee monopolistic structures for a certain time period and to achieve an adequate return on investment for innovation expenditures. Transferring the well established patent system from the manufacturing sector to the service sector may be a possible solution but that, on the other hand, raises some major problems. First, patents can only be applied for new technical solutions; therefore the international patent classification does not provide any service categories. Thus, only the service companies whose products have a technological base can protect their innovations by using patents. Furthermore, since a central driving force for innovations in the service sector is the recent development of information and communication technologies, patent activities tend to cluster and grow more rapidly in this field. Other kinds of patents are rarely found in service firms. Consequently, traditional protection mechanisms like patents cannot be obtained for most innovation activities of service companies. Other intellectual property rights mechanisms exist (like trademarks, copyrights), but until now not many theoretical and empirical insights have been investigated. This study tries to get a better understanding of the role of different protection tools as well as other forms of protection strategies within service-intensive companies.
Author Keywords: Intellectual property management; Service innovation; Strategies

Title: Determinants of entry timing: A study of semiconductor firms
Source title: Academy of Management 2006 Annual Meeting: Knowledge, Action and the Public Concern, AOM 2006
Abstract: I study the determinants of market entry timing and ask: How do early-movers differ from later entrants in their knowledge base? This question is at the core of first-mover theory, yet has remained unanswered due to inconclusive or contradicting results. I argue that the firm's technical, market, and manufacturing knowledge are crucial determinants of the firm's market entry timing and that firms endowed with these types of knowledge are more likely to be earlier product market entrants. The research setting is the semiconductor industry, where I analyze 53 international firms and their entry in 12 product generations. Results reconcile the contradictory findings so far: while I find broad support for the hypothesized facilitating factors, the interactions between these knowledge types impede an early product market entry.

Title: Technological discontinuities and organizational adaptation: Exploring the role of organizational identity
Source title: Academy of Management 2006 Annual Meeting: Knowledge, Action and the Public Concern, AOM 2006
Abstract: Different scientific fields consider identity as a pivotal concept when explaining behavior in general, and particularly, during change processes. I explore in this paper the merits of an identity-centered theoretical approach that might help to explain inertial as well as resiliency tendencies within organizations facing technological discontinuities. Specifically, I review empirical and theoretical evidence that seems to indicate that one key to understand how organizations can cope with these discontinuities is studying how organizational members come to understand their collective identity (i.e. organizational identity). Implications of this new approach are also presented.
Author Keywords: Organizational adaptation; Organizational identity; Technological discontinuities
Index Keywords: Change process; Collective identity; New approaches; Organizational adaptation; Organizational identities; Scientific fields; Technological discontinuities; Theoretical approach

Title: A strategy for improving insight at work
Source title: Academy of Management 2006 Annual Meeting: Knowledge, Action and the Public Concern, AOM 2006
Abstract: This study tests two ways to increase the likelihood of insight, the cognitive function that underlies creativity. This study empirically tests a theoretical model (Cronin, 2004) that suggests engaging in conscious activity will increase the length of time to insight. This study also tests how the content of the conscious work activity can help or hinder this basic process. Results support the idea that conscious activity lengthens time to insight, and that the relatedness of that conscious activity interacts with it to either bolster or diminish the effect, thereby refining the original model as well as validating it. The study concludes by discussing the prescriptions this model makes for individuals who want to be more creative working, and offers suggestions for how studying this model should improve group as well as individual creativity.
Index Keywords: Cognition; Cognitive functions; Creativity; Individual creativity; Insight; Original model; Theoretical modeling; Work activities

Title: The temporal dynamics of the divestiture process
Source title: Academy of Management 2006 Annual Meeting: Knowledge, Action and the Public Concern, AOM 2006
Abstract: Despite their major theoretical and practical relevance, the temporal dynamics of the divestiture process - including aspects such as the starting and ending point of the divestiture process, the timing of divestiture announcements, the lag between divestiture announcement and operative actions, the unfolding of these actions, and the importance of different time views (objective vs. subjective) more generally - have remained unexplored. The longitudinal, event-based study of how Siemens, Europe's largest electronics' company, divested its semiconductor business and two other electronic components' units in the late 1990s addresses this broad set of unresolved issues. Specifically, the paper unravels the starting and ending point of the divestiture process and highlights potential determinants both for the starting point (e.g., capital market's subjective time view) of the process and for the timing of the actual announcement of the divestiture decision. Moreover, the paper documents the different stages in the unfolding of the divestiture process. It unravels the lags and sequence in which actions occur and outlines how different "time clocks" and subjective time views impact on the entire process. Thereby, the current paper contributes to extant research by a.) revisiting and revising taken for granted assumptions on the temporal dynamics of divestitures (e.g., its starting and ending point), b.) by extending current knowledge in respect to the timing of divestiture announcements, c.) by acknowledging not only the importance of objective but also subjective time views, and d.) by generating new insights into the unfolding, sequencing and timing of multiple divestitures.
Index Keywords: Different stages; Electronic component; Event-based; Paper documents; Semiconductor business; Siemens; Temporal dynamics; Dynamics

Title: Success, failure and the gray zone: How organizations learn or don't from ambiguous experience
Source title: Academy of Management 2006 Annual Meeting: Knowledge, Action and the Public Concern, AOM 2006
Abstract: A long standing body of work emphasizes that organizations learn from experience by transforming continuous measures of performance into dichotomous outcomes of success and failure. This dichotomy creates a simple heuristic for prescribing behavior: persist when succeeding, change when failing. At the same time an emerging stream of research on mindfulness has started to focus on how organizations learn (or don't) from ambiguous and heterogeneous experience. I connect these literatures arguing that conventional models of organizational learning do not consider how organizations learn (or don't) from outcomes that fall between success and failure.
Index Keywords: Conventional models; Dichotomous outcome; Gray zone; Measures of performance; Organizational learning

Title: Redheaded eskimos: A barrier-based view of corporate political activity
Source title: Academy of Management 2006 Annual Meeting: Knowledge, Action and the Public Concern, AOM 2006
Abstract: We propose a conceptualization of corporate political activity in terms of barriers. This constitutes an attempt at applying competitive strategy concepts to CPA in order to improve our understanding of political rivalry dynamics. We argue that firms can earn a competitive advantage thanks to favorable state of public policy by raising barriers to political access, influence and policy advantage. This approach contributes to answering three key questions for firms considering political involvement, namely whether to get involved or to be a free-rider, when to get involved (before barriers are erected by rivals) and how to benefit from CPA (by raising barriers). This framework helps also to understand key differences across national political systems (pluralist Vs corporatist configurations) where access and influence conditions can vary greatly.
Index Keywords: Competition; Barrier; Competitive advantage; Competitive strategy; Free-riders; Lobbying; Political activity; Political systems; Public policy

Title: Radical strategic and structural change: Occurrence, antecedents, and consequences
Source title: Academy of Management 2006 Annual Meeting: Knowledge, Action and the Public Concern, AOM 2006
Abstract: Over time, firms tend to develop relatively stable strategies and organizational arrangements. Radical departure from such patterns is infrequent, yet sometimes necessary to enable improved organizational performance and survival. Research on radical organizational change has often either focused on the occurrence of large simultaneous changes in various organizational dimensions, treating them collectively as a single transformational event, or studied in depth a specific type of radical change without incorporating the occurrence of and interrelationships with other proximate radical organizational changes. In this study, we treat key types of radical change as separate yet interrelated events, rather than as subsumed parts of single events or as isolated from other organizational changes. We examine key factors that increase the chances that organizations will accomplish two high-impact types of radical organizational change-strategic and structural-and examine the performance consequences of each type of change. Our analysis of a sample of bank holding companies over two decades suggests that: (1) radical structural change occurs more frequently than radical strategic change; and (2) radical strategic change increases the likelihood that radical structural change will follow, but not vice versa. We also found that sustained low performance and the replacement of a top executive by an outsider facilitate the occurrence of radical strategic, but not that of structural change. We found that the effects of both types of change on firm profitability and survival were generally not significant. We discuss the implications of these findings for future research on organizational change.
Index Keywords: Firm profitabilities; Holding company; Organizational change; Organizational dimensions; Organizational performance; Stable strategies; Strategic changes; Top executive; Strategic planning

Title: The selective synthesis of competing logics
Source title: Academy of Management 2006 Annual Meeting: Knowledge, Action and the Public Concern, AOM 2006
Abstract: This research contributes to our understanding of organizational and social movement theories by showing how competing logics are selectively integrated as social groups formalize. With in-depth ethnographic studies of the Burning Man and Open Source production communities, we compare how these two growing communities developed formal organizations. We show how these communities reconfigured their organizational forms to address two competing, yet co-existing, logics: one emphasizing the need to coordinate production as they scaled in size and one emphasizing the need to exemplify members' interests. We find that these communities' members integrated organizing practices in ways that enhanced organizational sustainability but also supported espoused goals of reflecting members' interests. However, members rejected practices that violated their mission and norms. Members could not reconcile all practices to mutual satisfaction, so these practices remain contested. This research specifies how organizational innovation unfolds through members' consideration of competing logics and demonstrates how formal organizing practices can support rather than transform goals.

Title: Secondary stakeholder actions and the selection of firm targets
Source title: Academy of Management 2006 Annual Meeting: Knowledge, Action and the Public Concern, AOM 2006
Abstract: In this paper, we advance the stakeholder theory literature by developing and testing a set of hypotheses concerning which firms are likely to be targeted by secondary stakeholder groups. To test these hypotheses, we draw upon a unique dataset of stakeholder actions within the United States concerning environmental issues over the period 1988 to 2003. We find evidence for two clusters of stakeholder groups, each using different tactics and targeting different populations of firms. In general, we find firms that are more consumer-oriented, financially sound, and heavier polluters are more likely to be targets of environmentally-oriented stakeholder actions.

Title: The Nez Perce leadership council: A historical examination of postindustrial leadership
Source title: Academy of Management 2006 Annual Meeting: Knowledge, Action and the Public Concern, AOM 2006
Abstract: While historical examinations of individual leaders and various forms of leader behavior are often portrayed in the management history literature, more macro views of the relationship of influence amongst leaders and followers has rarely been described. In the attempt to alleviate this oversight, I examine the leadership council of the non-treaty Nez Perce, a celebrated Native American tribe, as an exemplar of Rost and Smith's (1992) notions of a postindustrial approach to leadership.

Index Keywords: Management history; Native American Tribes; Nez Perce; Postindustrial leadership

Title: The role of offender motives and victim reactions to social undermining
Source title: Academy of Management 2006 Annual Meeting: Knowledge, Action and the Public Concern, AOM 2006
Abstract: Integrating key components of previous models of attribution and prosocial and antisocial behavior, this study proposed and tested a model of victim reactions to social undermining in a lab and a field study. Findings suggest that victims of an intentional offense distinguish between offender motives of malice and greed, and further that these attributions shape subsequent retaliation, avoidance, and reconciliation through perceptions of offense severity and feelings of anger and sympathy.

Title: Causal ambiguity, operating complexity and strong capabilitybased advantages
Source title: Academy of Management 2006 Annual Meeting: Knowledge, Action and the Public Concern, AOM 2006
Abstract: The presumed connection between causal ambiguity and sustained, capabilities-based performance advantages is well-known to strategy researchers. This paper presents the first formal examination of this connection. I provide a precise distinction between the intrinsic, or potential, level of causal ambiguity associated with a particular strategy and the actual level that obtains in equilibrium. I find that intrinsic ambiguity is a necessary but, contrary to the speculation of some, insufficient condition for a sustained capability-based advantage. Most importantly, I also find that the complexity of the network of causal relations induced by a firm's strategy is not positively correlated with its intrinsic level of ambiguity. This contradicts earlier conjectures that have found their way into mainstream thinking.

Title: The (ir)responsibility of multinational enterprises
Source title: Academy of Management 2006 Annual Meeting: Knowledge, Action and the Public Concern, AOM 2006
Abstract: This paper contributes to the discussion on international diversification and corporate social responsibility by suggesting that firms can be both socially responsible and irresponsible simultaneously. To test our assertions, we analyze data from 222 publicly traded U.S. firms from 1993 to 2003. The findings support our hypotheses, which have significant implications on the way in which we conceptualize corporate social responsibility.

Title: Social capital effects on relational performance improvement: An information processing perspective
Source title: Academy of Management 2006 Annual Meeting: Knowledge, Action and the Public Concern, AOM 2006
Abstract: Strategic buyer-supplier partnerships, and the ability to leverage social capital within those relationships, are increasingly cited as a key driver of value creation. Despite the importance of strategic partnerships, however, the process by which social capital accumulates and contributes to performance improvements is not well understood. Drawing on information processing theory, we develop a model linking increased relational embeddedness, established through buyer and supplier commitments to a strategic relationship, to subsequent improvements in relationship performance. Furthermore, we hypothesize that structural embeddedness, as reflected in levels of formal impersonal communication, and formal and informal managerial and technical communication is positively related to relational performance improvements. We consider the ability of these various forms of communication to address the need for uncertainty and equivocality reduction in the relationship. Using data provided by 111 procurement executives from the United Kingdom, we find support for many of our hypotheses. The study extends the supply chain management literature and suggests important implications for both research and practice.

Title: A signalling theory of strategy
Source title: Academy of Management 2006 Annual Meeting: Knowledge, Action and the Public Concern, AOM 2006
Abstract: We still lack an integration of stakeholder and strategy theory. While existing literature has made advances by focussing on structural issues, such as the configuration of stakeholders in terms of multiplicity and fragmentation, this leaves out of account significant perceptual and cognitive issues, which here are termed 'transmission' issues. We argue that these 'transmission' issues can be best approached by the use and extension of signalling theory. The concepts of signalling space, signalling channels, a portfolio of signals, and signalling packages are introduced. This allows us to re-consider firm-level strategy as a flow of signals. A model of the signalling process is presented and some of the theoretical implications for strategy and stakeholder theory are discussed.
