Title: Work with toil: Moving beyond good work to redeemed work
Source title: Academy of Management 2006 Annual Meeting: Knowledge, Action and the Public Concern, AOM 2006
Abstract: Research in Organizational Behavior (OB) and Human Resource Management (HRM) is increasingly focused on examining personal meaning at work, but not much of this work is from an explicitly faith-informed worldview. Christian theology from a Neo-Calvinist perspective can lead to the development of a more nuanced approach to addressing work beyond simply a generally positive orientation. Particularly, the Christian themes of Creation, Fall and Redemption are used as a framework to analyze current management theories and to prescribe further perspectives on the nature and meaning associated with work. The themes of Creation and Fall are consistent with two underlying paradigms of work ideology found in common theories in OB, MSR and HR Management literature: One paradigm reflects a more positive, hopeful view of human nature and work, and can be found in concepts ranging from empowerment, trust, justice, vocation, OCBs, servant leadership and forgiveness. The second paradigm focuses on the "dark side" of organizational life and includes concepts such as job stress, role conflict, absenteeism, grievances, unethical or illegal behaviors and shirking. We suggest the need for the development of a third paradigm, drawn from the Christian theme of Redemption, which recognizes the tension between work as it was intended at Creation, and work that has been marred by the Fall - i.e., "toil." Such a perspective requires the understanding that there is a dark side to human nature and work itself, but that individuals can and should utilize their creative capacity to move toward the possibility of redeeming work.
Author Keywords: Christian theology; Management theory; Redeemed work
Index Keywords: Behavioral research; Employment; Planning; Christian theology; Human nature; Job stress; Management theory; Organizational behavior; Redeemed works; Role conflicts; Servant leadership; Human resource management

Title: Boundary-spanning behaviour and performance: Influence in a business services setting
Source title: Academy of Management 2006 Annual Meeting: Knowledge, Action and the Public Concern, AOM 2006
Abstract: Frontline service employees are the organization's boundary-spanning personnel, those employees at the boundaries of the organization - in close contact with outsiders of the organization. They have a strategic function, being placed between the external environment and the internal organization. By delivering the service to customers, frontline service employees and their behaviour have a great impact on organizational performance. Boundary-spanning behaviour relates to the behaviour of customer-contact employees of service firms that derives from their unique position as boundary spanners and is tailored to the unique context of service organizations. Antecedents of boundary-spanning behaviour such as role stressors and organizational fairness have been discussed in previous research. The impact of boundary-spanning behaviour on organizational relevant outcomes such as organizational performance is less explored. This research study investigates the impact of boundary-spanning behaviour on performance productivity and quality in a business services setting. Data from 1174 frontline service employees is analyzed using structural equation modelling. The results indicate that the three types of boundary-spanning behaviour - service delivery, internal influence and external representation behaviour - influence performance productivity. Performance quality is only affected by those behaviours targeted at outsiders of the organization: service delivery and external representation behaviour. Opportunities for future research and limitations of the study are discussed. Managerial implications focus on procedures to increase each of the three boundary-spanning behaviours and as a consequence, enhance performance productivity and quality.
Index Keywords: Productivity; Boundary-spanning behaviours; Business service; External environments; External representations; Managerial implications; Organizational performance; Performance; Structural equation modelling; Personnel

Title: Location within the field and the institutional construction of manager's cognition
Source title: Academy of Management 2006 Annual Meeting: Knowledge, Action and the Public Concern, AOM 2006
Abstract: We demonstrate that differential location in an institutional field leads to a differential impact of institutional pressures on the cognition of actors. We measure the adoption of a set of management techniques called "Manufacturing Best Practices". Our indicators of differential location in the field are whether respondents are public or private, large or small, subsidiaries or independent firms, and technologically sophisticated or unsophisticated. We argue that the first of each pair is more embedded in institutional discourse, as a consequence of differential location in the field, and therefore more likely to acquire institutionalized cognitions. Our indicator of cognition is the extent to which the configuration of practices adopted corresponds to the normatively preferred configuration. We find that firms which are more tightly linked to the field are more likely adopt the practices which are central to the category (in the sense of Rosch or Barsalou's work on category structure) and less likely to adopt the practices which are peripheral.
Index Keywords: Best practices; Institutional pressures; Management techniques; Location

Title: Global sensing and sensibility - A multi-stage matching assessment of competitive advantage from foreign sources for innovation
Source title: Academy of Management 2006 Annual Meeting: Knowledge, Action and the Public Concern, AOM 2006
Abstract: We focus on a core competitive capability of a modern firm: The ability to deliver successful innovations in a globalized environment. Companies literally find themselves confronted with a world of ideas. The challenge remains to decide which impulses should be on top of the list and which at the bottom. Given limited resources and substantial investments, betting on the wrong horse can be risky and costly. Theoretically integrated in capability based view of the firm we investigate firms' capabilities to assimilate, identify and prioritize valuable knowledge across national, cultural and social borders; a competence which we call global sensing. We establish an analytical framework to examine whether global sensing activities generate competitive advantage. Consequently, we develop an empirical, multistage evaluation strategy. The latter rests on a matching approach for a recent, broad sample of almost 1,700 German companies from both services and manufacturing. We find the strongest and most consistent support for global sensing as a strategic enabler for technological leadership. Apart from this strategic advantage we observe that foreign external sources for innovation are generally not superior to domestic ones.
Index Keywords: Competitive advantage; Competitive capabilities; Evaluation strategies; External sources; German companies; Global sensing; Strategic advantages; Substantial investments; Competition

Title: A comparison of acquirer and target perspectives on acquisition success
Source title: Academy of Management 2006 Annual Meeting: Knowledge, Action and the Public Concern, AOM 2006
Abstract: Focusing on technology intensive firms, I compare acquirer and target firm appraisals of acquisition success to value captured by key target firm stakeholders, namely employees, customers, investors, and the target firm's strategic initiative. Findings suggest that an acquirer will regard an acquisition as successful when the target's post-acquisition ability to innovate has been served, but that a target firm, and more specifically a selling entrepreneur, will regard an acquisition as successful when their private entrepreneurial aspirations have been served.
Index Keywords: Strategic initiative; Technology intensive firms; Mergers and acquisitions

Title: Corporate environmental strategy: Extending the natural resource-based view of the firm
Source title: Academy of Management 2006 Annual Meeting: Knowledge, Action and the Public Concern, AOM 2006
Abstract: In this paper, we integrate the results of various empirical studies which build upon Hart's (1995) seminal paper, published in the Academy of Management Review a decade ago. We identify two primary streams of research within the natural resource-based view of the firm which investigate alternatively the antecedents and the consequences of corporate environmental strategy. We extend Hart's natural resource-based view in two main ways. First, in terms of consequences, we explicitly consider how environmental investments in particular resource domains (as manifestations of corporate environmental strategy), can support the development of firm-specific capabilities, thus showing specifically how corporate strategy can lead to competitive advantage. Second, in terms of antecedents, we place the natural resource-based view approach in a broader organizational context, which takes into account parameters such as ecocentric leadership and related values as the drivers of environmental investments. While rooted within the natural resource-based view, our integrative framework is able to accommodate findings from empirical environmental studies grounded in other traditions. We use our integrative framework to advance recent debates within the resource-based view and corporate environmental strategy literatures. It is investments in specific resource domains, not environmental strategy per se, ultimately determine environmental performance.
Index Keywords: Competition; Investments; Natural resources; Competitive advantage; Environmental investments; Environmental performance; Environmental strategy; Environmental studies; Integrative framework; Organizational context; Resource-based view of the firm; Environmental management

Title: Towards a contingency theory of knowledge exchange in organizations
Source title: Academy of Management 2006 Annual Meeting: Knowledge, Action and the Public Concern, AOM 2006
Abstract: Building on qualitative data, we model how individual agents, rather than organizational units or firms, search and exchange knowledge. We use the fine-grained model to suggest moving away from the "more is better" approach to knowledge exchange towards a more contingent approach. Employing an agentbased modeling approach, we present three synthetic experiments and derive testable propositions. First, we propose that the higher the individual learning rate, the lower the returns on organizational knowledge exchange and thus the lower the differences between exchange and non-exchange organizations, and between different exchange configurations. Second, we propose that the lower the problem complexity, the lower the returns on organizational knowledge exchange, with similar organizational consequences. Third, we propose that there is an inverted U-shaped relationship between the size of individual memory and the returns from knowledge exchange. We conclude by calling for a greater consideration of direct and opportunity cost in organizational knowledge exchange.
Index Keywords: Social networking (online); Individual learning; Knowledge exchange; Organizational knowledge; Organizational units; Performance; Problem complexity; Reciprocity; Synthetic experiments; Knowledge management
